summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against Daniel Heath Kight, a convicted felon who was sentenced to life imprisonment without benefit of parole, probation, or suspension of sentence for the second degree murder of David Scasino (“Scasino”).  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Vinton, Louisiana on March 26, 2018, alleges that Kight was a victim of the mandatory minimum sentence imposed by the Louisiana legislature in 2014.  According to the complaint, Kight had a long history of substance abuse, was bipolar, schizophrenic, and off his psychiatric medication, and had a history of drug-related psychosis.  Kight allegedly told a 9-1-1 dispatcher that he would kill his victim and rip his genitalia off.  The complaint further alleges that he claimed to know right from wrong at the time of the crime and that he had smoked weed, gotten mad at the caller, and caused the victim to lose his entire head.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for New Orleans today announced criminal charges against Kight for his role in the alleged scheme.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the complaint in the SEC's Complaint, the defendant consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay a civil penalty of $75,000, which is equal to the amount of his criminal conviction.  On March 27, 2019, the court granted Kight's motion for a preliminary injunction against further violations of the federal securities laws, ordered him to be held in a rehabilitation center, and imposed a mandatory life sentence of life imprisonment with no pre-judgment interest, and ordered Kight to be placed in the regular population at Angola or "probably a lot of other state facilities."  In its order granting the injunction, the SEC also instituted a parallel criminal action against the defendant, who was convicted in a separate criminal case in which the same defendant was convicted of the same criminal case.  To determine whether Kight is entitled to a downward departure from the mandatory sentence, a judge or jury must determine whether he has met the burden of proof required by the federal law.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-1052 (January 24, 2019).
